awd_titl_txt: FET: Small: Weak and Continuous Quantum Measurements with Feedback
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the strangest aspects of quantum mechanics is quantum measurement. Rather than simply revealing information about a system, a quantum measurement causes an unpredictable disturbance in the system's state, and it is impossible to gain information about a quantum system without disturbing it. There are weak measurements that cause little disturbance, but these must inevitably also reveal very little information. A sequence of weak measurements, one after another, produces a continuous measurement, where both information and disturbance accumulate over time. This project concerns weak and continuous quantum measurements, and combines them with feedback, where the accumulated information is used to adapt the measurements while they are being done. These methods have many applications, to quantum computers, high-precision measurements (or metrology) and other quantum technologies. They also provide a powerful theoretical tool for understanding quantum theory.

This award will study many aspects of weak and continuous quantum measurements, but will focus on three areas in particular. 1) Destructive (or lossy) weak measurements: many physical systems---such as light---cannot be easily measured except by being absorbed. Current technology includes only a limited set of quantum measurements of light; anything that extends this set would be an exciting development. 2) Continuous quantum error correction: quantum computers are highly susceptible to noise, or decoherence. These techniques would continuously monitor a quantum computer and reverse errors as they occur, perhaps even preventing them by the quantum Zeno effect. 3) Quantum resource theories: resource theories study properties of quantum systems, like entanglement, coherence and free energy, that can be exploited for useful tasks. Continuous measurement theory can quantify resources using monotones, which diminish or increase steadily as the resource is consumed, analogous to how entropy grows with time in the second law of thermodynamics. Many more interesting properties and uses of weak quantum measurements are expected to appear in the course of this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As the title suggests, this project concerned weak and continuous quantum measurements with feedback. Quantum measurements typically result in a random change to the quantum state, a phenomenon called backaction. More specifically, if one acquires information about a quantum system by doing a measurement, the state must change, and the size of the change is related to the amount of information gained. A limit of this effect is a so-called weak measurement, in which only a very small amount of information is obtained, and the random change of the state is also small. This limit can be used to describe continuous measurements, in which information is accumulated over time, and the changes to the state also occur incrementally; one can think of this as a sequence of weak measurements.

This project applied this concept theoretically to several topics in quantum information science and computation, with one additional element: feedback. As information is acquired in a continuous measurement, it is used to apply a control to the system’s evolution. Several specific problems were tackled using these tools, with some results achieved and others the subject of ongoing research.

1. Continuous quantum error correction. A major limitation on quantum computers is that they are greatly affected by noise—that is, by errors in the computation. The main countermeasure is to use error correction: the information is protected by an error-correcting code, and measurements are done periodically to diagnose and correct any errors that have occurred. In continuous quantum error correction, one is constantly monitoring for errors and applying corrections throughout. While technologically challenging, this has advantages, in that certain types of errors (called “non-Markovian”) are actually suppressed or prevented by the continuous measurements, even without correction.

2. Enhanced performance of quantum devices through feedback control. We specifically looked at single photon sources, which are designed to emit precisely one photon on demand in a given mode. This is experimentally hard to do, both because the emitted photons may be noisy, and the exact number emitted may be random: zero photons, one, or more than one. In earlier work we showed that continuous monitoring and feedback could reduce the noise; in this project we showed that it could also improve the probability of emitting exactly one photon.

3. Hitting time in quantum walks. Quantum walks are quantum-mechanical analogues of random walks, where a particle can move randomly on a graph from one vertex to any of the neighboring vertices. In the quantum cases, the particle can move in superpositions of different directions, and they exhibit new kinds of behavior due to interference, which can lead to either faster or slower traversal from one vertex to another. Quantum walks are important models of quantum algorithms and other quantum systems. This research studied the hitting time of quantum walks—the average time to arrive at a specific location—using a continuous measurement to determine when the particle arrives, and showed how the symmetry of the quantum walk can cause large changes in this hitting time.

4. Quantum resource monotones. A relatively new paradigm in quantum information science is the idea of a resource theory, where a property of a quantum system (such as entanglement or coherence) is quantified as a measurable resource for carrying out some information-processing task (such as quantum teleportation). One method of quantifying resources is with monotones, functions that diminish as the resource is used up in carrying out the task. It is possible to find equations for monotones using continuous measurements. This project supported work on quantifying one such resource, the non-Markovianity of a quantum channel.

These outcomes are some of the results from the research supported by this NSF grant, and feed into the ongoing research effort in quantum information science, just as they build on results from earlier research. Quantum information science remains an active and vibrant field, with both important applications and questions of great theoretical interest.
